orientation.title: Statement
orientation.statement:
There are 3 sections to this project.

Each section contains 4 to 5 pieces of text and an image that relates to said text.

You will decide whether each image belongs in your personal exhibition.

Your decisions are your response to the text.

There are no limits and no wrong answers, I merely ask that you consider each work.

works.framing_text: Photography at its core is the act of creating an image by recording light.
works.context_text: Walker Evans. Interior near Copake, New York. 1933, Gelatin Silver Print.

works.framing_text: Must photos contain light, or is its absence just as valid?
works.context_text: Michael Lo Bue, Picture of a window with lens cap on, unedited.

works.framing_text: Must this record match how we as humans experience the world?

works.context_text: Gary Nichols, 10th place in Nikon 1982 Photomicrography, Single crystal of barium titanate with impurities mounted in immersion oil, polarized, 28x magnification.

works.framing_text: The photo is an index of light, the captured phenomena is a fact.
works.context_text: Michael Lo Bue, photo of a window with blinds closed.

works.framing_text: When do we recognize a shift?
works.context_text: Michael Lo Bue, Photo of a window with blinds open (same settings).
Michael Lo Bue, photo of a framed tree.
Michael Lo Bue, photo of maximum light exposure.

works.framing_text: When is the index utterly destroyed?
works.context_text: Michael Lo Bue, photo of maximum light exposure with pixels painted over with white.

works.framing_text: The boundary of photography is the index, the “fact”. Its expansion lies in implication of something more than truth.
works.context_text: Philippe Halsman, Dali Atomicus, 1948, Gelatin Silver print.

works.framing_text: Can a photo be more than a moment?
works.context_text: Michael Lo Bue, picture of pouring colored water.

works.framing_text: Can it capture sound? Or scent?
works.context_text: Stephen Shore, Beverly Boulevard and La Brea Avenue, Los Angeles, California, June 21, 1975.
Moneta Sleet Jr, Correta Scott King and Daughter Bernice at the funeral of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 1968, Gelatin Silver Print.
